description: Assessment and treatment of the young child in ambulatory care settings is the focus of this developmentally organized course. This course provides the nurse practitioner student with the necessary knowledge and experience to assist individuals with the most common health problems, including acute episodic illness as well as stable chronic disease. The concepts of health promotion and health maintenance are integrated throughout the curriculum. Using a developmental framework, the maturational tasks and problems of children and their families in relation to illness and health are explored.
name: CLINICAL MANAGEMENT OF PRIMARY CARE WITH YOUNG FAMILIES

section.name: CLINICAL MANAGEMENT OF PRIMARY CARE WITH YOUNG FAMILIES

values.comments:
Assessment and treatment of the young child in ambulatory care settings is the focus of this developmentally organized course.  This course provides the nurse practitioner student with the necessary knowledge and experience to assist individuals with the most common health problems, including acute episodic illness as well as stable chronic disease.  The concepts of health promotion and health maintenance are integrated throughout the curriculum. Using a developmental framework, the maturational tasks and problems of children and their families in relation to illness and health are explored.
	Students described this class as “awesome” and “valuable.”  Occasionally viewed as an “incredibly difficult” course, this class provided a level of depth in to the content that students appreciated.  Some wished that the notes were provided before lectures so that students would be better able to prepare, and a few thought that the science paper was busy work.  Despite these few things that students would change, most viewed the class as fantastic and as one that would give them “an edge when entering the working world.”
No specific comments were given in regards to Professor O’Sullivan, but all of the professors were seen as “supportive” and “accessible.” 
Many students felt that the structure of the course was not laid out clearly, and as such, the tests were difficult and oftentimes not based on covered material.  A common complaint was that more time was needed for tests and labs, but that the “material was very valuable.”  Comments revealed that all tests and quizzes were seen as “fair,” but that it would be helpful if clinical guidelines were spelled out a little more clearly.  Prerequisites for this course are NURS 656 and 657, with a corequisite of NURS 659.

section.name: CLINICAL MANAGEMENT OF PRIMARY CARE WITH YOUNG FAMILIES

values.comments:

	Students described this class as “awesome” and “valuable.”  Occasionally viewed as an “incredibly difficult” course, this class provided a level of depth to the content that students appreciated.  Some wished that the notes were provided before lectures so that students would be better able to prepare, and a few thought that the science paper was busy work.  Despite these few things that students would change, the majority viewed the class as fantastic and as one that would give them “an edge when entering the working world.”

Many students felt that the structure of the course was not laid out clearly, and as such, the tests were difficult and oftentimes not based on covered material.  A common complaint was that more time was needed for tests and labs, despite the “material [being] very valuable.”  Comments revealed that all tests and quizzes were seen as “fair,” but that it would be helpful if clinical guidelines were spelled out a little more clearly.  Prerequisites for this course are NURS 656 and 657, with a corequisite of NURS 659.
